sentence: Technology stocks pared earlier declines in late afternoon trading with shares of technology companies in the S&P 500 falling about 0.4%.

In company news, Salesforce.com ( CRM ) rallied Wednesday, with shares of the customer relationship management software firm climbing to an all-time high after it was said to be working with investment bankers to field potential take-over offers after recently being approached by a would-be buyer.
There is no certainty any deal will transpire, according to a Bloomberg report, citing people with knowledge of the matter.
The people also would not identify potential suitors, with one of the sources saying the bankers may either help to rebuff certain offers or to work out an eventual sale.
CRM shares were up slightly more than 11% in late afternoon trade at $74.28 each, earlier topping out at a record high of $78.46 a share.
Prior to today's surge, the stock already had risen more than 44% over the past year.
(+) MSTR, Adjusted Q1 EPS of $2.11 trumps Street view by $1.15 per share.
Revenue slips 10.2% from last year to 123.9 mln, trailing Capital IQ consensus by around $11.32 mln.
(-) SSYS, Falls to three-year low after saying it expects Q1 revenue in a range of $171 mln to $173 mln, trailing consensus view by $26.3 mln.
Non-GAAP EPS seen between $0.02 to $0.04, lagging estimates by at least $0.24 per share.
